title: RS22055
content: The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) provides federal funding for children with disabilities to receive a free appropriate public education (FAPE). The act, enacted in 1975, ensures due process for FAPE and includes provisions for attorneys' fees. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) ensures that states provide education for children with disabilities, with provisions for attorneys' fees added in 1986 by the Handicapped Children's Protection Act. Amendments in 1997 and 2004 addressed attorneys' fees, including reductions for lack of timely information and exclusion for most IEP meetings. The 2004 IDEA reauthorization made changes to attorneys' fees, with the final version closer to the Senate bill and allowing fees for the state educational agency or local educational. The 2004 IDEA reauthorization made changes to attorneys' fees, allowing fees for the state educational agency or local educational agency against the parent or their attorney in certain situations. The new law maintains general provisions for filing complaints and appeals, with the addition that the local educational agency may also file a complaint. Parents or LEAs can file complaints regarding various educational aspects and have the right to an impartial due process hearing. Attorneys' fees are determined based on prevailing community rates, with specific prohibitions and restrictions in place. The 2004 reauthorization of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure added a requirement for a "resolution session" before a due process hearing in special education cases. The final regulations for P.L. 108-446 were issued on August 14, 2006, with the Department of Education declining to provide further guidance on the interpretation of statutory language regarding attorneys' fees in special education cases. The Department of Education declined to address whether non-attorney advocates could receive fees in special education cases, citing that lay advocates are not entitled to compensation as attorneys.
